bwwExcerpt: It is hard though where to place the blame. Fundamentally, this play seems like a bad piece of writing. Willimon has no other significant playwrighting credits, a fact that surprises no one in the audience. Other than the clear genre confusion previously mentioned, the dialogue itself is completely overwrought, robotic, and simplistic, often complete with odd one-liners and bon mots that only Oscar Wilde could pull off. But some blame must also go to the director, Pam McKinnon, whose most recent
showScoreExcerpt:
"At its most painful moments, an incredibly obvious political commentary void of any nuance...Fundamentally, this play seems like a bad piece of writing...The staging of the show was often awkward and incredibly unnatural...The men of the production were basically intolerable and miserable to watch. But in their defense, their characters were horribly written and had to contend with some of the most stilted dialogue to be heard on Broadway in the last decade."
